security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing markdown guidelines and checklists. No scripts, no code execution, no network access, no file system access beyond its own content.

content.value_statement: Security reviews require structured guidance to identify vulnerabilities consistently. This skill provides comprehensive checklists and frameworks like NIST, OWASP, and MITRE ATT&CK for thorough security assessments.
actual_capabilities: Conduct security reviews using industry frameworks (NIST, OWASP, CIS Controls)
Apply threat modeling with STRIDE methodology for each trust boundary
Audit web applications against OWASP Top 10 and ASVS checklists
Review smart contracts for reentrancy, access control, and economic attacks
Assess ZK circuits for constraint soundness and transcript binding
Verify supply chain integrity using SLSA and OpenSSF Scorecard
limitations: Does not execute code or run automated security scanning tools
Cannot access external systems, APIs, or vulnerability databases
Provides guidance only; does not replace manual expert security audits
Limited to checklist-based review without dynamic analysis capabilities

use_cases.title: Conduct Threat Models

use_cases.title: Audit DeFi Protocols

prompt_templates.title: Basic Code Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code for security issues using the security-audit skill. Check for injection vulnerabilities, access control weaknesses, and cryptographic misconfigurations.

prompt_templates.title: Threat Modeling
prompt_templates.prompt: Conduct a threat model for this architecture using STRIDE. Identify trust boundaries, authentication strategies, and potential attack paths.

prompt_templates.title: Smart Contract Audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Audit this smart contract for security vulnerabilities. Check reentrancy patterns, access control, oracle dependencies, and economic attack vectors.

prompt_templates.title: Supply Chain Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Assess this repository supply chain security using SLSA and OpenSSF Scorecard guidelines. Check dependency pinning, build integrity, and CI/CD controls.

output_examples.input: Review this authentication module for security issues
output: ‚Ä¢ Session tokens not rotated on privilege changes
‚Ä¢ No rate limiting on login endpoint
‚Ä¢ Consider implementing step-up auth for sensitive actions

best_practices: Always start with threat modeling before deep-diving into specific vulnerabilities
Use the STRIDE framework to systematically identify potential attack vectors
Document findings with severity levels and reference relevant framework controls
anti_patterns: Skipping access control checks because endpoints are 'internal only'
Using client-side validation as the sole protection against injection attacks
Assuming cryptographic implementations are secure without verifying algorithm choices

faq.question: What frameworks does this skill reference?
faq.answer: NIST CSF 2.0, CIS Controls v8, NIST SSDF, OWASP ASVS, OWASP Top 10, MITRE ATT&CK, SLSA, and OpenSSF Scorecard.

faq.question: Can this skill scan my codebase automatically?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides checklists and guidance for manual review. It does not execute code or run automated scanners.

faq.question: Does it work with all programming languages?
faq.answer: Yes, the frameworks are language-agnostic. Checklists cover general security principles applicable to any codebase.

faq.question: Is my code data sent to external services?
faq.answer: No, this skill operates entirely within your AI session. No code or data leaves your environment.

faq.question: How does it handle smart contract audits?
faq.answer: It references smart-contract-checklist.md covering reentrancy, access control, oracles, upgradeability, and economic attack vectors.

faq.question: Should I use this instead of a professional audit?
faq.answer: No, this skill complements but does not replace professional security audits. Use it for preliminary reviews and ongoing security checks.
